name: 維多利亞時期文學
goals: Throughout the course, we will consider the function of speculative fiction, examine the relationship between science and literature, and strengthen our academic writing skills
syllabus:
Seminar in Victorian Literature: Victorian Horror

National Taiwan Normal University, Fall 2021

Wednesdays, 9:20-12:10

Dr. Justin Prystash                                                 

Office: Cheng 720                     

Office Hours: W 15:20-17:10; F 11:20-13:10; Virtual Meetings by Appointment

Email: jsprystash@gmail.com               

**Course Description**

This class will highlight one important strand of Victorian literature: the horror genre, which emerged in its modern form in concert with Gothic literature across the long nineteenth century. We will focus our attention, however, on the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. I am particularly interested in exploring the type of horror sometimes called “metaphysical” or “cosmic” horror, and we will read a wide range of fiction—especially short stories, but also some novellas—associated with this subgenre. We will also become familiar with various theoretical and critical approaches to horror, and we will watch two films that further investigate the themes of the class. 

**Texts**

Many of our readings are short stories, and I will provide PDFs of them. You will need to procure your own editions of the two novellas we will read: William Hope Hodgson’s _The House on the Borderland_ and H. P. Lovecraft’s _At the Mountains of Madness_. I’ve ordered them at Bookman, which is across the street from NTU. 

**Assignments**

Attendance/Participation   20%

Seminar Paper (10+ pages) 80% 

**Attendance/Participation**

This is a graduate seminar. Seminars are not meant to be lecture-based, but discussion-based. That means you need to participate in order for us to have a successful seminar (it also means that I need to regularly fade away from the center of the class). Although I will guide our discussions, I expect you to come to class familiar with that week’s assigned reading(s), ready to ask questions and have fruitful discussions and debates. I will take attendance every week. I will also regularly hold in-class group “games” where you will analyze and/or synthesize passages from our texts and share your perspectives with the class. 

                 
**Seminar Paper**

This is the usual assignment given at the end of a graduate seminar: an academic essay, similar in style and organization to published essays that appear in academic journals. They must focus on one of the texts we read this semester, they cannot be used in any other seminar, and they cannot be plagiarized.

**Schedule**

Week 1, 9/22: Introduction; Syllabus Review

Week 2, 9/29: Historical Overview: Jerrold E. Hogle, “Introduction: The Gothic in Western Culture”; Royce Mahawatte, “Horror in the Nineteenth Century: Dreadful Sensations, 1820-1880”; Roger Luckhurst, “Transitions: From Victorian Gothic to Modern Horror, 1880-1932”

Week 3, 10/6: Theoretical Approaches: Selections from Jonathan Newell, _A Century of Weird Fiction, 1832-1937_; Eugene Thacker, _In the Dust of This Planet_; and Mark Fisher, _The Weird and the Eerie_  

Week 4, 10/13: Short Stories by Arthur Machen

Week 5, 10/20: Short Stories by Arthur Machen  

Week 6, 10/27: Short Stories by Vernon Lee    

Week 7, 11/3: William Hope Hodgson, _The House on the Borderland_

Week 8, 11/10: Short Stories by Algernon Blackwood  

Week 9, 11/17: Short Stories by Algernon Blackwood 

Week 10, 11/24: Movie Week: _Picnic at Hanging Rock_ (1975)

Week 11, 12/1: Short Stories by Robert W. Chambers 

Week 12, 12/8: Short Stories by H. P. Lovecraft

Week 13, 12/15: H. P. Lovecraft, _At the Mountains of Madness_

Week 14, 12/22: Short Stories by M. R. James 

Week 15, 12/29: Short Stories by M. R. James

Week 16, 1/5: Movie Week: _Annihilation_ (2018)

Week 17, 1/12: Flex Week (No Class Meeting)

Week 18, 1/19: Flex Week (No Class Meeting): Seminar Paper Due; Upload to Moodle before Midnight
